The resulting figure as well as the HTML which shows the alt text for the image." --- ## `fig-alt` You can add alternative text to figures you create with code by adding the `fig-alt` chunk option, which works for Knitr, Jupyter, and Observable code chunks. Here is an R/Knitr example. ::: {.cell} ````{.cell-code} ```{{r}} #| label: penguins-plot #| warning: false #| fig-alt: | #| Scatterplot of penguin bill depth vs. length, colored by species. #| The relationship is positive for each of the three species. library(tidyverse) library(palmerpenguins) library(colorblindr) ggplot(penguins, aes(x = bill_length_mm, y = bill_depth_mm, color = species)) + geom_point() + scale_color_OkabeIto() ``` ```` ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](index_files/figure-html/penguins-plot-1.png){fig-alt='Scatterplot of penguin bill depth vs. length, colored by species. The relationship is positive for each of the three species.' width=672} ::: ::: The resulting HTML is shown below. This alternative (`alt`) text is accessible to screen readers. ``` html ``` ## Learn more Quarto chunk options: - [Jupyter code chunk options for figures](https://quarto.org/docs/reference/cells/cells-jupyter.html#figures) - [Knitr code chunk options for figures](https://quarto.org/docs/reference/cells/cells-knitr.html#figures) - [Observable code chunk options for figures](https://quarto.org/docs/reference/cells/cells-ojs.html#figures) Guidance for writing alt text: - [Writing Alt Text for Data Visualization](https://medium.com/nightingale/writing-alt-text-for-data-visualization-2a218ef43f81) - [Charts & accessibility](Charts & Accessibility)
